comments:
This course, a senior studio in architecture, is a continuing exploration of architectural design. Content and technique in representation and construction are explored through various studio design exercises.

Some students felt the course, as a landscape architecture course, “fell short.” Some did not feel they had gained a sufficient knowledge of landscape architecture throughout the course, and others found the curriculum to be “unorganized.”

Students enjoyed learning from Professor Leatherbarrow, calling him “amazing.” Students felt Professor Leatherbarrow was “genuinely excited about [their] development as architects,” and “able to inspire [them] to develop [their] work.” However, many students said that Professor Leatherbarrow “seemed like a guest lecturer, rather than a real professor,” and that “the infrequency of his appearance in class was disruptive.”

Students found themselves to be “at a standstill throughout most of the semester,” until the final project, the size of which many students found to be “too large for the amount of time given and the detailed research and design that was expected.” Many students felt the expectations in the course were “unrealistic and unclear.”

*8 respondents

This course, a senior studio in architecture, is a continuing exploration of architectural design. Content and technique in representation and construction are explored through various studio design exercises.

Some students felt the course, as a landscape architecture course, “fell short.” Students did not feel they had gained a sufficient knowledge of landscape architecture throughout the course, and others found the curriculum to be “unorganized.”

Some students found Professor Brandt to have “amazing concepts for design” and a way of “pushing everyone to their fullest.” However, students felt her methods of communication “sometimes backfired because of her emotional way of dealing with students.” Furthermore, students had difficulty communicating with Professor Brandt, citing her “emotional nature,” which inhibited a creative environment and open discussion forum. While students said Professor Brandt offered to help students outside the classroom, “she often did not arrive when she said she would or did not come at all.”

Students found themselves to be “at a standstill throughout most of the semester,” until the final project, the size of which many students found to be “too large for the amount of time given and the detailed research and design that was expected.” Many students felt the expectations in the course were “unrealistic and unclear.”

*8 respondents
